{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2973357,"name":"Lyle Oxley","username":"ParaKnight","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/6bbea6/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T02:54:36.729Z","cooked":"

Does anyone have any user instructions for using the Omio X8 for cutting Lexan sheet? All of the students that have knowledge of how to use this graduated over the last two years and we weren’t allowed in the building last year so kind of starting from scratch. We would love to find step by step instructions for getting a drawing from Inventor all the way through cutting on router.

I thought there would be a user instructions post but couldn’t find one when I search C/D.

Thanks for your help.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T02:54:36.729Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":734,"reads":315,"readers_count":314,"score":3733.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Lyle Oxley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49691,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2973365,"name":"Justin Montois","username":"Justin_Montois","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/justin_montois/{size}/1512_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T04:27:08.102Z","cooked":"

Do you know what CAM software you have used in the past to generate your Gcode?

That will help you locate someone who can help the best.

If you aren’t sure I’d recommend the CAM feature in Inventor. That’s what we use and it fits into our workflow perfectly (as we do our CAD in inventor as well)

We have written some Guides about using CAM to generate GCODE on our docs site:
https://docs.team4909.org/guides/intro-to-cam/

We don’t have an OMIO but I believe the Mach3 software is the same as we use on our Velox CNC Router. This guide might be helpfull:
https://docs.team4909.org/guides/running-the-velox/

Here is a thread on speeds and feeds for Polycarbonate (Lexan).

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T16:07:23.404Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":255,"readers_count":254,"score":91.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"FrankJ","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/feeds-and-speeds-for-lexan/365164","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"Feeds and speeds for lexan","clicks":65}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":15944,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"2974 Robot Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/4","custom_user_title":"2974 Robot Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973413,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T17:32:48.484Z","cooked":"

It’s been a while, but these are the settings I’ve used for for cutting Poly on an OMIO:

For 1/4" Diameter Endmills:

  • RPM: 5000
  • Cutting Feed: 9in/min
  • Ramp Feed: 9in/min
  • Plunge Feed: 3in/min
  • Max Stepdown: 0.1 in

For 1/8" Diameter Endmills:

  • RPM: 9000
  • Cutting Feed: 9in/min
  • Ramp Feed: 9in/min
  • Plunge Feed: 3in/min
  • Max Stepdown: 0.1 in

Other notes:

  • Enable Finishing Pass on final depth (Helps compensate for material flex during first pass)
  • 2-Flute Endmills preferable, 3-Flute works too if needed, just be careful of chip buildup; note that endmills with fewer flutes generally require higher RPMs, and vice-versa.
  • If possible, keep the work surface clean as it’s cutting, either with compressed air or by vacuuming any chips away (
  • Don’t be afraid to override the settings in MACH3 if it seems to be cutting weird (loud, struggling), you can always increase the RPM or decrease the feed, but note that this will result in more heat build-up. Generally, I’ll run a new cut at 50% feed just to see how it starts, then gradually increase back to 100% if it seems to be working ok.

The biggest problem with the OMIO X8 is that it doesn’t have a lot of torque compared to other CNCs, so it’s easy to stall the motor if you’re not careful. If you run into too much heat buildup (melting plastic) lower your RPM and/or increase your feedrate; if doing this starts to stall the motor, decrease your depth of cut.

Some other OMIO tips for those unfamiliar:

  • “Feed hold” pauses a job and allows you to resume again seamlessly, but it does NOT stop the machine instantaneously
  • The “Stop” or “E-Stop” commands/button will stop the machine immediately, but you will likely need to re-home everything and start the job again from the beginning, as the machine may loose it’s place.
  • Always re-home after a tool change to avoid potential position drift in the stepper motors
","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T17:32:48.484Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":14,"reads":252,"readers_count":251,"score":145.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973417,"name":"Devin Castellucci","username":"RoboChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T17:58:43.655Z","cooked":"

Those seem very slow to me. That 1/8 inch cutter should be doing at least 16k for plastic. The 1/4 inch I’d be starting at around 12k rpm as a baseline.

For aluminum on an Omio router I’ve done 24k rpm with a 4mm cutter at 45 IPM and 0.090 DOC. You can push that way harder.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T17:58:43.655Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":210,"readers_count":209,"score":142.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Devin Castellucci","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6560,"username":"cbale2000","name":"Chris Bale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7460,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/6","custom_user_title":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973424,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T18:16:00.925Z","cooked":"

We used to run it faster, but we kept melting plastic and breaking endmills.

I can’t even imagine running aluminum that fast. With a 1/4" Aluminum-specialized 2-flute endmill we ran at 12k rpm, 0.0625" DOC, and 5-9IPM and we were literally setting the wood under the aluminum part on fire (it still has the scorch marks) because of the heat buildup on the aluminum.

Now we run at 15IPM, 6000RPM, 0.0125" DOC (the DOC change was the important one) for aluminum with a 1/4" endmill and it works fine. Takes a while, but doesn’t break any cutters.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T18:18:54.962Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":205,"readers_count":204,"score":71.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7460,"username":"RoboChair","name":"Devin Castellucci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/7","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973426,"name":"Devin Castellucci","username":"RoboChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T18:19:51.561Z","cooked":"

How many flutes are on your endmills?

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T18:19:51.561Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":196,"readers_count":195,"score":74.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Devin Castellucci","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6560,"username":"cbale2000","name":"Chris Bale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7460,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/8","custom_user_title":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973427,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T18:21:33.825Z","cooked":"

2-flute or 3-flute (with slightly different settings, obviously). We broke most of our 2-flute cutters attempting the 0.0625" DOC parts before a Journeyman machinist told us to back off on it.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T18:21:33.825Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":195,"readers_count":194,"score":49.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7460,"username":"RoboChair","name":"Devin Castellucci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973428,"name":"Devin Castellucci","username":"RoboChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T18:24:17.924Z","cooked":"

I HIGHLY suggest trying some single flute endmills. They clear chips super well and that is likely the issue you have been running into with the plastic. Also you can redress the ends with a bench grinder and a sharpening stone if they chip and keep using them way longer.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T18:24:17.924Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":192,"readers_count":191,"score":93.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Devin Castellucci","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6560,"username":"cbale2000","name":"Chris Bale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7460,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/10","custom_user_title":"1678 Fab Mentor and 5458 Tech Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973429,"name":"Chris Bale","username":"cbale2000","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T18:29:36.730Z","cooked":"

It’s less a problem of “chipping” and more the endmills just snapping in half when the spindle stalls, running the aforementioned 0.0625" DOC at ~12k RPM/5-9IPM.

The endmills we got were all donated from a local supplier who unfortunately does not offer them in single-flute… That said, if you have any tips for using 4/5 flute endmills on aluminum we have a TON of those (I’m kidding of course, don’t use 4/5 flute endmills on aluminum kids).

I’ll probably look into getting some single-flute endmills after FTC settles down.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T18:29:36.730Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":4,"reads":189,"readers_count":188,"score":67.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7460,"username":"RoboChair","name":"Devin Castellucci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973430,"name":"Devin Castellucci","username":"RoboChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T18:36:48.653Z","cooked":"

Do you know if the cutters you have are carbide or are the HSS? If they are HSS those speeds and feeds are actually pretty good.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-26T18:47:37.359Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":15,"reads":181,"readers_count":180,"score":111.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Chris Bale","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://fullertontool.com/search?&tool_type_id=EM&uom=imperial&end_type_id=S&series_id=3825&number_of_flutes=2&cutting_diam=0.2500&popout=38218","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Search Carbide Tools by Tool Type, Spec or Material | Fullerton","clicks":30}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7460,"username":"RoboChair","name":"Devin Castellucci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robochair/{size}/161076_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6560,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/13","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973480,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-26T23:52:08.442Z","cooked":"
cbale2000:

It’s less a problem of “chipping” and more the endmills just snapping in half when the spindle stalls, running the aforementioned 0.0625" DOC at ~12k RPM/5-9IPM.

Something is very wrong if you are stalling the 2.2kW spindle on an Omio X8 at super-slow rates like that in plastic. Just for perspective, here is an Omio X8 at 100 IPM, 0.25 DOC, 0.06 stepover in aluminum. It’s not slotting, but it’s impressive performance. There are plenty of other videos showing the Omio performing similarly.

If you are heating aluminum enough to scorch the spoilboard, you have probably already melted aluminum onto the cutting edges of the bit turning it effectively into a 1/4" rod trying to push through aluminum by high-speed rubbing. It’s going to get ugly in a hurry. I still wouldn’t expect a 2.2kW spindle to stall before breaking a bit though.

I’m not an Omio owner, but it seems like there may be problem with your spindle or VFD.

","post_number":16,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-27T02:29:32.955Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":45.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Lyle Oxley","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":12397,"username":"techplex","name":"Blake Bourque","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/techplex/{size}/195570_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":49691,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/16","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973502,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-27T02:38:22.036Z","cooked":"

Just wanted to clarify something here. Mach3 and Inventor CAM (or just any CAM program in general) are two very different things. A CAM program will generate G-code for you of the part you’re looking to make.

Mach3 on the other hand is a program/interface used to control your CNC and stream G-code to the machine itself.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-27T02:38:22.036Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":15,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":13,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":111.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":49691,"username":"ParaKnight","name":"Lyle Oxley","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/6bbea6/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/17","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973514,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-27T03:40:21.777Z","cooked":"

As echoed above, these are very slow feedrates. My starting feeds and speeds for Huhao single-flute carbide endmills are:

Aluminum
4mm endmill: 24k RPM, 50 IPM, 0.05" DOC slotting
6mm endmill: 20k RPM, 80 IPM, 0.1" DOC slotting

Polycarbonate
4mm endmill: 22k RPM, 75 IPM, 0.1" DOC slotting
6mm endmill: 18k RPM, 100 IPM, 0.14" DOC slotting

The endmills I use for practice are this brand: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32847714937.html but WCP and Ozzyboards endmills work even better.

Too low of an RPM will stall these kinds of spindles. They are not really designed for operation below ~8k RPM. 12k+ RPM is where I like to run them. Furthermore, too low of a chipload (IPT divided by RPM) will cause tons of rubbing and melt things/get them very hot. Always maintain proper chipload for the tool. Reduce width of cut or depth of cut if you need to, but chipload should always be in the correct range.

For aluminum, you can start at 0.001" IPT chipload per 2mm of tool diameter for a single flute endmill. Polycarb can be 1.5x faster, possibly more.

There is one tutorial I liked some time ago that used HSMworks: https://youtu.be/kMmyWzoGliY which is fairly standard for a CAM program. I prefer Fusion CAM for its updates and powerful “templates” that let you CAM standard jobs in extremely little time. I know some people also like Cut2D or SheetCAM for their router-specific features, such as nesting.

If you need help or a walkthrough of how to use CAM, feel free to PM me and we can set up a time.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":24,"updated_at":"2021-10-27T03:40:36.905Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":18,"reads":154,"readers_count":153,"score":165.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396810,"topic_slug":"omio-router-user-instructions","display_username":"Anand Rajamani","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.aliexpress.com/item/32847714937.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"HUHAO 5pcs/lot Single Flute Spiral Cutter Router Bit Shank 4mm CNC End Mill For Acrylic Carbide Milling Cutter Tugsten Steel|router bit shank|cnc end millend mill - AliExpress","clicks":10},{"url":"https://youtu.be/kMmyWzoGliY","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":7}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":6560,"username":"cbale2000","name":"Chris Bale","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cbale2000/{size}/2142_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":21715,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/omio-router-user-instructions/396810/18","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973538,"name":"FrankJ","username":"FrankJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/frankj/{size}/5392_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-27T13:05:16.249Z","cooked":"

Sort of the basic work flow. This is the Wiki simple version If you are already posting code to your machine, you have already figured it out.

Design the part. OP’s case Inventor

Cam the part in Inventor needs the HSM plugin. If you have the Cam tab in Inventor it is installed. Camming is where the speeds and feeds are set via tool selection. You can define tools in the tool library with the speed and feed or do it in the individual tool path.

Post process from Inventor. The generate the G code used in the Omio.This where you pick the machine. For an Omio it uses Mach3. While G code is generic not all machines interpret G code in the same way so it important to use the right configuration for your machine.

Run the G-code on the Omio. The Omio uses Mach3 to convert G-code to machine movement. Mach3 is used on many generic machines by DYI and companies too small to write there own interpreters.
The process is similar using Cad packages other than inventor. I have no experience with Onshape, but I am a little surprised you can not do it from Onshape.
